Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a High Performance Computing Cluster to Enhance the Undergraduate Discovery Experience

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will fund the acquisition of a graphical processing unit (GPU)/central processing unit (CPU) hybrid high performance computing cluster (HPC) to enable undergraduate research and education. The cluster will be used for high impact research, discovery, and learning across several disciplines encompassing Biology, Chemistry, Computer Science, Geography, Material Science and Engineering, Mathematics, and Physics. The additional compute capacity will promote research-embedded classrooms and integrating computational science into the standard curriculum. It will provide a significant push to student development, code development, program profiling, system tuning, and system administration. In addition the infrastructure will enable discovery of modeling and simulation technologies that may elucidate molecular mechanisms for drug delivery, computational design catalysts for renewable energy and chemical synthesis, advanced computational analysis tools for next generation informatics and big data, and improved understanding of risk and resistance to breast cancer.

The instrumentation will serve studies that employ hybrid quantum/classical simulations, for example investigation of the influence of protein dynamics on catalysis and inhibitions involving electron transfer and group reaction in two important families of enzymes (quinine reductases and aminoacyl-tRNA synthetases). The inhibitory mechanisms in these proteins are actively studied in the development of drugs with anti-cancer and anti-pathogenic properties. These studies may pave the way to design mechanism-based inhibitors of these enzymes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF MRI Grant fund was used to purchase a high-performance computer cluster. The CRAY/Hewlett Packard Enterprise high-performance computer cluster has been received on December 21, 2020 by UW-Eau Claire Learning and Technology Services (LTS). Although the cluster has been placed temporarily at the Regional Data Center of the Chippewa Valley Technical College (CVTC), a High-Performance Computing Center (HPC Center) is being designed at the new Science Building, which will host the HPC cluster.

Intellectual Merits

The main goal was to obtain enough funding to purchase a high-performance computing cluster for UW-Eau Claire to support the research and teaching need of the campus as well as its sister campuses. Once entering the production phase, the new 61-node 3904-core CRAY cluster, with an estimated 10-fold increase in the computational power compared to the existing one, will provide a significant boost to undergraduate discovery and education.

Faculty research. One of the shared objectives of the UW-Eau Claire is to provide research opportunities to each undergraduate student of the campus. The campus possesses a smaller cluster, which has served as main computing tool for several research project delivering authentic research to a large number of STEM students. These research projects have led to important scientific discovery on the role of oxidative stress on the severity of COVID-19 and novel materials for the next-generation energy storage (https://www.uwec.edu/academics/college-arts-sciences/academic-resources/academic-facilities/blugold-supercomputing-cluster/publications/). However, the need for research projects has greatly exceeded what can be offered by the current cluster. Thus, the new cluster is expected to provide the much-needed computational power for the PIs, senior personnel, and other faculty and staff members for continuous scientific discovery involving undergraduate students. Furthermore, a growing number of faculty members from a few sister campuses, including UW-Stout and UW-River Falls, have benefited from the computational resources at UW-Eau Claire.

Teaching involving computing.  The HPC cluster will foster several of the existing courses such as Biophysical Chemistry, Computational Material Science, and Computational Chemistry. In addition, the NSF-MRI cluster will boost a proposed computational science minor by bridging computational courses of Physics, Material Science, Mathematics, Computer Science, and Chemistry, educating the next generation computational scientists and engineers.

 

Broader Impacts

Bringing HPC to high school teachers & students. UW-Eau Claire plans to offer High Performance Computer (HPC) training to high school teachers. We believe Computational Science will become one of the major ways that research will be conducted and by training high school teachers how to use our HPC, we will enable those teachers to be able to incorporate Computational Science concepts into their curriculums. This will enable us to prepare the next generation of scientists by giving them the necessary skills they will need to make Computational Science research more approachable. Initially the training will be implemented as a set of online self-study training courses that can be accessed remotely via the internet. The training courses will be self-paced and available on demand and will not be affected by social distancing or other pandemic related influencers. Beyond the pandemic, our plan is to offer an annual HPC summer bootcamp for high school teachers.

Student training & workforce development. In addition, the HPC cluster is providing opportunities to create training opportunities for UW-Eau Claire students in high performance cluster technology. Undergraduate students, supervised by a staff member from LTS, will be in charge of the maintenance of the cluster. Such a maintenance model has been extremely valuable for these students to develop skills in system administration, scripting and software optimization that are not available in a classroom setting. Furthermore, the CRAY/HPE Cluster will create a collaboration between the local HPE Assembling and testing Unit and the UW-Eau Claire. This will create internship opportunities for a large number of students belonging to the Science and Engineering departments.

Serving sister campuses and local communities. Incorporating computational sciences to undergraduate curricula that breaks disciplinary boundaries has become increasingly important to educate the next-generation scientists and engineers. Here at UW-Eau Claire, a computation science minor is being proposed and supported by the administration. However, other universities, especially regionally liberal arts colleges, often lacks the computational resource to provide a meaningful computational experience. This MRI grant has enabled the creation of the Blugold Center for High Performance Computing, the only center of its type at a comprehensive university in the UW System and in Wisconsin. The center will provide necessary computational resources for interested faculty members at sister campuses. The proposed computational science minor will also explore ways to be offered to students at sister campuses. The center will also outreach to local industries and communities to promote high performance computing and to establish possible collaborative projects. One example is the collaboration between UW-Eau Claire and Mayo clinic, and this new HPC cluster will provide computational resources that could enable discoveries in medical sciences.
